The policy has been included in the Access to Public Information Act, the Ordinance on the standard terms and conditions for public sector information reuse and its publishing in open format, which contains specific provisions regarding publishing and reuse of public information in open format and in Decisions of the Council of Ministers approving the List of data sets by priority areas to be published in open format annually. The Act and the Ordinance settle the provisions regarding the right of access to public information, as well as the reuse of the public sector information. 
Pursuant the Electronic Government Act the Ministry of e-Government (MEG)  issues methodical guidelines and supports the administrations in defining the structure and contents of the datasets to be published on the Open Data Portal of the Republic of Bulgaria under the Access to Public Information Act.

Justification:
Referring to EU high value datasets, the publication and access to geospatial datasets will be greatly enhanced. 
A National Spatial Data Portal providing Spatial Data Services to national and European users is in operation since 2021. The Portal is linked to the European Geo-spatial Portal. It provides public assess to sharing interoparable spatial data, in full compliance with the INSPIRE Directive. 
https://inspire.egov.bg/

The development of the National Spatial Data Portal is listed among the priority measures in the Strategy.

The measures related to the national open data portal aim to stimulate the publication and access to citizen-generated data. The portal allows anyone to post data regardless of whether they are a citizen or an organization. There is a separation in the designation of data from official sources (ie public sector organisations) and data from citizens. However the guidelines, publication process and tools are the same whether the data provider is a ministry or a journalist, activist, student. 
Enhancing the contribution of citizen science and citizen-generated data is also supported by the Research, Innovation and Digitization for Smart Transformation Programme.

According to the national policy, all open government data has to be published via data.egov.bg. This ensures the discoverability and reusability of data.
The National Open Data Portal is the single point and meeting place between administrations, organizations (including research, business and government) and citizens interested in opening up public information and developing modern data-based services. Coordination of open data activities is carried out by the Electronic Identification and Data Unit in the Ministry of e-Government to facilitate interaction with the various target audiences. It ensures compliance with European standards and ensures the possibility of synchronizing national data with those at the European level.
All data which is published on the National Open Data Portal (data.egov.bg) is discloverable on European Data Portal (data.europa.eu).

Justification:
Each public sector body shall annually plan the phased publication on the Internet in an open format of the data sets and resources it maintains, access to which it is free.  The executive authorities shall include in the annual activity objectives of the relevant administration under Article 33a of the Administration Act aims to ensure the phased publication on the Internet of the data and resources included in the Lists of annual priority data sets.

The open data principles are embedded in the National Updated eGovernment Strategy 2019-2025 - https://egov.government.bg/wps/portal/ministry-meu/strategies-policies/strategic-documents
The Strategy provides for:
- the implementation of a Registry reform, which clearly provides for open data;
- decreasing the use of unstructured data;  
obligatory compliance with the open data principle (data generated by the public sector shall be in an open 
-machine-readable format, allowing for their reuse)

The Act and the Ordinance settle the provisions regarding the right of access to public information, as well as the reuse of the public sector information.

Justification:
In 2021-2023 the focus is on identification of High Value Dataset LIst based on the Sixth Priority Categories at EU level.We worked actively to identify datasets in every category, checking for legislation and/or technical barriers at nation level hindering their publication and we facilitated the publication process. The Open Data team conducts regular meetings with the stakeholders, especially the public sector bodies in order to support the prioritisation of datasets to be published in open format. Based on that, as well as on the surveys previously conducted, we cooperate with the stakeholders to finalise the lists of priority datasets. 

Based on the above, we included  the identified top 2 datasets with high priority in the country in the next Decision of the Council of Ministers in 2022, adopted on pursuant APIA art. 15b (3), according to which “The Council of Ministers shall annually, on the proposal of the Minister of Electronic Governance, adopt a list of data sets to be published in open format on the Internet”.

A working group has been established in connection with the implementation of the tasks set out in it, arising from the obligations under Regulation (EU) No. 2022/868 on a European framework for data management and amending Regulation (EU) 2018/1724, and the Implementing Regulation ( EU) No. 2023/138 of the Commission of 21 December 2022 to determine a list of specific high-value data sets and the terms and conditions for their publication and reuse. A questionnaire was prepared and sent to the competent organizations, aiming to support and facilitate the work of fulfilling the obligations in the two regulations. Based on its feedback, an analysis will be made of the degree of readiness of the published data and of the existing challenges.

Ministry of environment and water is currently preparing a  strategy, which will an emphasis on the European Green Deal.
The Ministry of e-Government is also actively involved in the Green Deal policy, through initiatives of the European Commission such as Destination Earth.

The pandemic has demonstrated the growing importance of digitalisation for all aspects of the economy, society and government. It also reaffirmed the need to build high-speed digital connectivity and harness the potential of data by removing barriers to data sharing. This complex environment has shown that artificial intelligence and robotics can provide many solutions to improve healthcare. Undoubtedly, the benefits of e-education and training and their social effect have been proven.

One of the major principles in the updated eGovernment Strategy 2019-2025 is openness and transparency: public administrations should share information and data between themselves and enable citizens and businesses to access control and correct their own data; enable users to monitor administrative processes that involve them; engage with and open up to stakeholders (such as businesses, researchers and non-profit organisations) in the design and delivery of services.
In full consideration of this principle, the vision of the Strategy for 2025 foresees the introduction of digital tools for civil involvement as a means to establish a modern citisen-oriented administration.

Ministry of e-Government is such structure in the country. The Open Data Team acts as a National Open Data Policy Coordinator and a Global National Open Data Portal Administrator. It is part of the Strategic e-Government Planning Department, e-Government Policies Directorate. 
There are Data Officers in every administration (according to the Access to Public Information Act), Working Groups, informal Open Data Forum Group, National Open Data Portal, public consultations and good national coordination policy.

A centralized approach is chosen because it helps the efficient implementation of the open data policy. It allows Ministry of e-Government to track difficulties encountered by data publishers and data users which leads to a faster improvement throughout the received feedback from data users.
Strong central coordination is used for creating basic administrative capacity in the leading administration in conducting the open data policy.
As a result from coordinated and joint work led by the MEG, only a key expert from each administration in involved in the open data processing of the respective public body. This will reduce the administrative burden in other administrations.
Public bodies use a single person of contact regarding open data in the MEG.

The public organizactions on central, local, and regional level are involved in working groups on concrete open data topics under Ministry of e-Government. 
There are regular annual trainings, events and personal assistance in the initial process of publication of the data for new data officers. Mainly regional and local structures participated in them.

There is a regular exchange of knowledge between the two fully engaged experts with more than 7 years of experience in the team and some partly engaged experts for the activities regarding the National Open Data Policy (incuding National and European Legislation and Policy, Coordination, Working Groups, Initiativies like trainings; events; promotion; technical and metodological documents; questionnaires and reports) and National Open Data Portal (including updating technical specifications, proposals for development, administering and updating the content, creating new sections, granting access rights and roles, verifying data and metadata, supporting data officers and administrators from public sector organisations in the process of data publication and  communicating regulary with the technical team for out-of-warranty technical support of the portal.There are monthly requests and reports between techical team of the portal and open data team in MEG before every payment.

Pursuant to Article 8, paragraph 3 of the Ordinance on the standard terms and conditions for public sector information reuse and its publishing in open format the heads of public sector bodies designate officials - administrators of profiles (Data Officers)  who upload the data for the organization concerned and publish the information of the Open Data Portal. This is a version of the role of “data officer” in the public sector bodies. A draft ordinance is prepared, where we clarify the duties of the data officer and the term “administrator of profile” is to be replaced with “data officers”.
The governance model also includes working group activities, online meetings/communication between administrators of profiles and state for: reports with questionnaires addressed to administrators of profiles; feedback, problems and communication via emails; online support from the main administrator of the National Open Data Portal.
https://egov.government.bg/wps/portal/ministry-meu/home/data/open-data/legislation/opendata-legal-national/

here is regular communication via phone, email, online meetings, regular trainings etc. All data officers are part of a natinal open data network coordinated by the open data team. The contact database is kept accurate and up-to-date. Furthermore, each organization is legally obliged to submit timely information about any changes of the designated data officers.

A cooperation agreement with the GATE Institute has been signed: https://data.egov.bg/news/view/51
A regular exhange of knowledge is also transferred within the Working group on transposing the Open Data Directive, which is comprised by experts from the public sector bodies, the academia, business, NGO's and citizens.

o Each year, since the Directive 37/2013/EU was implemented in the national legislative framework, the Council of Ministers adopts action plans for gradual opening of the numerous datasets in prioritised fields. This action plans are in the form of a Decision of the Council of Ministers, which includes also the list of datasets to be published in the current year by the public bodies. So far, the adopted decisions are as follows: Decision No. 103 of the Council of Ministers (CoM)dated 17 February 2015 on approving the List of data sets by priority area to be published in open format;
o Decision  No. 214 of the Council of Ministers dated 25 March 2016 on approving the List of data sets by priority area to be published in open format;
o Decision No. 897 of the Council of Ministers dated 21 October 2016 on amending and supplementing  of Decision No. 214 of the CoM dated 25 March 2016
o Decision No. 436 of the Council of Ministers of 04 August 2017 on the adoption of a List of data sets by priority area to be published in open format on the Open Data Portal
o Decision No. 54 of the Council of Ministers of 01 February 2019 on the adoption of a List of data sets by priority area to be published in open format on the Open Data Portal
Decision No. 435 of the Council of Ministers of 03 July 2020 on the adoption of a List of data sets by priority area to be published in open format on the Open Data Portal
Decision No. 567 of the Council of Ministers of 30 July 2021 on the adoption of a List of data sets by priority area to be published in open format on the Open Data Portal
Decision No. 406 of the Council of Ministers of 23 June 2022 on the adoption of a List of data sets by priority area to be published in open format on the Open Data Portal

There are annual reports to track progress of data publication against these plans. Each administration fulfill online form for its progress which form is verified from national open data team. We monitor if: 1. the administration has published new datasets in open machine-readable format for the relevant year; 2. Datasets are included in annual priority lists or are published proactively by the administrations; 3. Datasets are included in an approved schedule for publishing; 4. Datasets are published within the deadline, with delay or are not published at all.

In accordance with the current legal framework in Bulgaria and through the Law on Access to Public Information, information from the public sector is provided for reuse free of charge or after payment of a fee, which cannot exceed the material costs of reproducing and providing the information. There are certain exceptions to this principle.
The processes used to identify Public Sector Organizations that charge data fees beyond marginal costs are a result of data requests received from interested parties.
The data department team analyzes the processes of pricing and payment of the data above the marginal costs, identifies the high value data according to the competence of the relevant administration, which should be published in an open machine-readable format on the Portal. A connection is established between the data holders, the interested parties requesting the data and the data department as a mediator, and meetings are organized to establish the details of the method of providing the data and the legal grounds for their provision at the present time.
Once meetings are organized between the relevant departments or working groups are formed, the purpose of which is to review the legal basis for the creation, maintenance and dissemination of the relevant data sets. The relevant regulations and documents defining the tariffs and fees are reviewed and, after assessing their importance and significance for users, a decision is made to provide the data with free access or up to marginal costs.
As a result, they are included in the annual list of data sets by priority areas, approved by a Ministerial Council Decision. The responsible administrations, for their part, should change their legal grounds for collecting fees for those included in the list of data approved by the decision of the Council of Ministers.

Open data is the public information collected, created and maintained by public sector organizations and published in an open machine-readable format (CSV, RDF, XML, JSON, etc.), allowing re-use for commercial or non-commercial purposes.
Reuse of public sector information is the use also for commercial or non-commercial purposes other than the original purpose for which it was created within the powers or functions of a public sector organization. The provision of public sector information to a public sector organization in connection with the exercise of its powers or functions is not reuse within the meaning of Access to Public Information Act. (Article 2a, APIA).

Justification:
https://bulgaria.representation.ec.europa.eu/novini-i-sbitiya/novini-0/novata-programa-nauchni-izsledvaniya-inovacii-i-digitalizaciya-za-inteligentna-transformaciya-beshe-2023-04-06_bg
https://strategy.bg/PublicConsultations/View.aspx?lang=bg-BG&Id=6993

In Bulgaria, there is an interest in the open data policy at the national level and to examine the level of re-use. Program "Research, Innovation and Digitization for Intelligent Transformation" (PNIIDIT) meets the strategic needs and priorities of Bulgaria for accelerated economic development through investments in the development of scientific research, scientific infrastructure, innovation and smart industry and the rapid entry of digital technologies into the economy and society. The program will support the unfolding of the potential of the data, which will lead to including supporting the introduction of the assessment methodology in the field of open data. Under PNIIDIT, a network of 12 European digital and information hubs will be built by applying the so-called synergistic European approach. Hubs are a key component of the innovation ecosystem and infrastructure by region, as their activity is directly aimed at helping SMEs and supporting the digital and innovation capacity of enterprises in key areas such as high-performance computing, artificial intelligence, cyber security and others.
The program will also support the digital transformation of the public sector and the deployment of the potential of data in strategic economic areas and spheres of public interest. Data spaces as part of the European data strategy are one of the tools for creating a single data market in the EU and hence in Bulgaria, in which data from different sectors - public institutions, private entities and citizens are used under the same, equal conditions and thereby promoting the development of innovation, growth and competitiveness. The creation of data spaces will support knowledge and technology transfer and create ecosystem linkages between stakeholders.

The National Open Data Portal has processes in place at national level to monitor the reuse of open data. Tools are available to measure reuse, including number of users, dataset views and downloads, and overall portal usage. Using Google Analytics and Tableau, these statistics are publicly available at https://data.egov.bg/statistika?section=1&item=1 and https://lookerstudio.google.com/reporting/20a22fa9-a6dc-4f09-9c7b -192d5b24d1d1/page/DsNMB?s=jyhzby8b7FY.
Also there are regular meetings with the Open Data Portal' Users. Their feedback, comments and suggestions on existing data are sought and invited to suggest additional data that may be useful to them.

The Network of Open Data Liaison Officers is a network of representatives of all Bulgarian public authorities, coordinated by the National Open Data Team. The Network of Liaison Officers meets periodically to discuss the promotion and monitoring of open data within their organizations and with stakeholders. Such an event was held in June in Pazardzhik, where Institute of Public Administration provided training together with the National Open Data Team
The National Open Data Team also uses this network to send information to all public bodies, such as information about events, training, new portal features and support. The members of this network are also the points of contact for specific inquiries about the reuse of data published by their organization, ensuring that requests and questions are responsive.
Regular open data training is also available to all public sector bodies, which includes the importance of re-using open data and the impact and how to measure re-use.

The impact leads to increased transparency, accountability, effectiveness and efficiency of government, the inclusion of marginalized groups, raising awareness and can help address a range of issues in different areas.

Each administration, according to Art. 15 of the Access to Public Information Act, prepares an annual report on the received applications for access to public information and for the reuse of information from the public sector, which also includes data on the refusals made and the reasons for this. The annual report is part of the annual reports under Art. 62, para. 1 of the Administration and Summary Information Act is published in the annual report of IISDA.
One section of the Council of Ministers report examines the implementation of the obligations of state institutions following the Access to Public Information Act (APIA) to adopt internal rules for work under the Access to Public Information Act, to publish certain categories of information on their websites and to provide explanatory information on the exercise of the right of access to information by citizens and legal entities.
An element of this part of the analysis is the data on the preferred form of obtaining the requested public information. The re-use summary section in the report is under development. results will be visible in next year report.

Justification:
The system for electronic budget payments (SEBRA) is a system for monitoring payments initiated by budget enterprises included in it and managing payments within pre-set limits. The implementation and improvement of SEBRA is a major component of the budget reform and, in particular, of the reform of the payment system for the budget sector, through which the following main goals are achieved:
- improvement of the budget payments and rationalization of the payment process by centralizing the monetary resource in BGN in the Bulgarian National Bank and decentralized management and control of the payments of the individual systems, through the relevant primary administrator;
- implementation of aggregated control and management of payments by setting a general limit for payments to the relevant budget appropriations, with a view to ensuring rhythmicity in the financing of state expenditures.
Achieved results:
- modernization, simplification and rationalization of cash management and budget execution;
- improving efficiency in the management of budgetary resources;
- limiting cash payments to the maximum extent;
- increasing fiscal transparency;
- improvement of fiscal discipline.

The National Environmental Monitoring System (NEMS) was created and functions according to Art. 1, item 7 of the Environmental Protection Act. The system provides timely and reliable information about the state of the elements of the environment and the factors that affect it, on the basis of which to make analyses, assessments and forecasts to substantiate the activities of protection and protection of the environment from harmful effects. The system is managed by the Minister of Environment and Water through the Environment Executive Agency. IAES administers the National Monitoring System on the territory of the entire country, providing the necessary material-technical, methodological and program-informational resources for its functioning and development. All measurements and observations are carried out by the structures of the Environmental Protection Agency according to uniform, uniform sampling and analysis methods in compliance with the procedures for ensuring the quality of measurements and data. All laboratories of IAES are accredited according to BDS EN ISO/IEC 17025 - "General requirements regarding the competence of laboratories for testing and calibration" by IA "BSA".
EAES maintains national and regional information databases. National and regional level databases are structured by environmental components using a common nomenclature.
Assessments of the state of environmental components and data reporting at the national level are carried out by the EEA; the assessments at the regional level - from RISU, the assessments and reports on the state of water resources at the basin level - from 4 Basin directorates for water management.
The system is organized according to the order of Chapter Eight of the ZOOS and includes the National Networks for the monitoring of: atmospheric air, waters, lands and soils, forests and protected areas, biological diversity, radiological monitoring and noise monitoring. The scope of NSMOS also includes the control and information systems for: emissions of harmful substances in the atmospheric air, emissions from waste water in water bodies, information system for waste, information system for soils, information system for biological diversity, automated system for radiation coverage - background.

Justification:
The strategic goals and priorities in the field of energy and climate of Bulgaria laid down in INPEC are as follows: Regarding the "Decarbonization" dimension, Bulgaria will make efforts to increase the share of energy from renewable sources in the gross final energy. consumption and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. On the recommendation of the EC, Bulgaria raised the level of ambition for the share of energy from renewable sources in the gross final energy consumption from 25% to 27.09%, thereby betting on achieving the calculated goal, according to Annex II to Regulation (EU) 2018/1999 In support of this goal, Bulgaria will build additional capacities with an emphasis on wind and solar energy. Also, if necessary to achieve the set goals after 2025, it is possible to hold tenders for additional capacities for energy from renewable sources, tailored to market conditions. Biomass use is projected to increase in all sectors: electricity, heat and cooling, and transport. The anticipated changes in the transport sector will have a significant impact on the development of energy from renewable sources, as well as on the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. More specifically, Bulgaria will promote the introduction and use of electric and hybrid vehicles in public and private transport, envisaging the creation of low-emission zones in major cities. These measures, among others, will contribute to a significant reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in Bulgaria.

Digital twins in Bulgaria
In Bulgaria, there are already several implemented projects for the construction of Digital Twins, with the main emphasis on temperature and climate changes, which are studied on the basis of artificial intelligence and LIDAR images (GATE Institute).
A scientific team from the National Center for Geospatial Research and Technologies at SU "Kliment Ohridski" -(https://ukh.uni-sofia.bg/hgis/team/) is also working very actively on the topic, working on several projects with urban heat islands (Anton Popov, Stelian Slavkov Dimitrov, Bilyana Borisova, 2019).
In a large part of the above-mentioned studies, the topic of landfills is advocated, which has been extensively researched by the author's collective of the National Research Institute of BAS, "Aerospace Data" Section (Dancheva, A. 2020; Dancheva, A., Nedkov). , R., Borisova, D., Spasova, T., (2019); Dancheva, A. and Asenovski, S (2018).
Impact: Urban heat islands are analyzed through open data and in relation to the Green Deal and impact the implementation of new projects and innovative solutions raising awareness of water quality and/or air quality, endorsing the thermal comfort of urban spaces, limiting pollination is improved, biological diversity is supported, etc.

Climate action means social justice. A key message of our leadership is that social justice and social well-being are intricately linked to the environment and climate. After all, it is the more financially vulnerable part of the middle class that always suffers more from the climate crisis than those who have a secure web of privilege and a sufficient financial buffer to absorb the brunt of this crisis. . These are the small farmers who are losing their livelihoods because of the drought, the elderly population who have to endure increasingly hot summers, the middle class people who live in the suburbs and commute to work constantly stuck in traffic, or who live along highways and industrial areas and constantly inhale harmful Preface Preface - 7 gases, or workers in automobile factories whose jobs are at risk because company management ignores the winds of change and clings too long to outdated technologies, missing out on too many business opportunities. Whether it is decentralized energy supply, sustainable transport or a just coal transition, where ex-coal workers are given sustainable 'green' jobs and thus secure a stable income for their families, ambitious climate policies help the people who would otherwise be hit hardest by the impacts of a rapidly changing climate. These policies give them security and prospects. By meeting the challenges of the current climate reality head-on, "green" policies put our lives and the lives of our children on a firmer footing.

There is evidence that the release of open data has led to an increase in the efficiency of some public bodies. For example, since the launch of the Agency for Sustainable Energy's portal, open data on different energy sources can be queried via APIs, rather than running custom queries and Excel exports for individual queries. Information seekers can now be directed to their open data API. Previously, it took a long time to respond to queries and the data was not up to date after the query was executed. A new reference was being prepared for the next applicant. Data is now dynamic and the burden on internal resources to manage data requests has been reduced.

The program for scientific research, innovation and digitalization for economic transformation is one of the instruments in response to the country's strategic needs and priorities for conducting a general policy for the development of scientific research and innovation in favor of accelerated economic development. On the side. This is also a response to the need to speed up the digitization processes of the public sector and build a favorable digital environment to guarantee quality and secure exchange of information between the different spheres of life and strengthen the effects of their interaction. This affects the level of adoption of new technologies.

The open data impact of the program is to expand the volume and improve the quality of open and spatial data in machine-readable format for reuse by business, the scientific community and citizens to create innovative services and products and add value to the economy and society . Also, the impact is expressed in building new models of interaction and data sharing between citizens, businesses and administration in a digital environment, as well as development of existing such relevant solutions and last but not least in promoting the conduct of marco-economic and micro-economic studies for the assessment of the impact of open data.

Impact Drive works to build individual and organizational capacity among those who create positive change for communities in Bulgaria.
They believe that real change can only be achieved with true equality for women, and they and their organizations are the main focus of our mission.
They achieve their mission by creating concrete solutions, projects and programs for inclusion, equality and development of personal and organizational capacity.
https://bgfundforwomen.org/bg/2022/05/04/mypath-project-2022/
The Bulgarian Fund for Women is part of the essential part of the development of the MyPath project under the European Union program in the field of education, youth and sports "Erasmus+", in partnership with three other organizations, in Austria, Germany and Portugal. The project "MyPath: Career planning - participation of medium and/or higher skilled migrant women and women from ethnic minorities in the labor market" includes companies and organizations from the non-governmental sector working in the field of retraining and combating unemployment, coaching and mentoring, as well as specialization in the organization of professional training and preparation.
The loss and weakening of work-related skills is a common barrier for migrant women, but also for women from ethnic minorities, who can often be overqualified for their jobs. Moreover, the emphasis on migrant women in the low-skilled sectors of the labor market and on the so-called 'male' sectors of the skilled labor market further obscures the presence of skilled migrant women in the labor market. As a result, skilled migrant and ethnic minority women across the EU continue to face challenges within and outside their communities that have a detrimental effect on their equal participation in society. Discrimination and social exclusion reduce their ability to seek their rights and place them in an extremely vulnerable situation where poverty and violence can mix in a closed circle. Barriers to employment are often lack of childcare opportunities, lower levels of working language proficiency, insufficient self-esteem and external support, and fixed cultural role models. To be successful in professional development planning, initial support such as empowerment and capacity building, as well as motivation building, is paramount.
The Bulgarian Fund for Women is an entity that influences equality policies and develops projects and initiatives to increase the participation of women in social life and the digital environment and data science with a gender perspective. It seeks to harness the potential of specific groups of people and promotes women's upskilling and data-based decision-making in its work.

In addition to the portal's mechanism for data requests that reach the designated responsible institution, the team in the data department receives each request in the general specialized e-mail and tracks the process of fulfilling the request. For certain cases in which the request is feasible but additional assistance is needed, the respective responsible institution is contacted, which is coordinated by the head of the department. In the reporting periods during the year, the implementation of the received data requests is reflected and the cases in which they are not fulfilled are analyzed. If necessary, additional actions are taken to implement them, when there is no valid or legal reason why they should not be fulfilled until they are provided and published on the Portal.

Answer: yes, or all public sector data providers already publish data
Justification: Trainings are organized for newly appointed employees, helping them to define the structure and its scope, to anonymize personal data, as well as to exclude information that is protected by a special law and remains outside the scope of open data. Meetings and working groups are organized to unify data from regional and local structures. At the moment, we are actively working with Basin Directorates, which are 4 in number for Bulgaria. A similar initiative is forthcoming with the regional administrations of education, making up 28 administrative structures.

In Bulgaria, the open data policy is centralized and in order to facilitate users in the adopted approach to publishing information in one place, therefore a unified national platform for publishing open data has been created, namely the national open data portal. All public sector organizations (central, local and regional) within the scope of the Access to Public Information Act have created a profile on the national portal. Citizens and non-governmental organizations can also publish data on it through their own profiles.
Besides the national open data portal thete aren't other regional or local portal because of the policy in the country.

The data is categorized as "disapproved" and falls into the appropriate category until it is reviewed for quality by one of the portal's administrators before it is published.

Newly created data sets are not previewed in the public part of the Portal until they are approved by an administrator. This functionality is built into the portal in order to have datasets that are certain to be presented in a machine-readable open format compliant manner with good quality of the information provided.
